conclusion: Analyze the v-t graph to determine if the particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds.
The graph shows velocity on the y-axis and time on the x-axis; velocity increases from 0 to 1 second, then decreases from 1 to 3 seconds.
Acceleration is the slope of the v-t graph; from 0 to 1 second, velocity increases linearly indicating constant positive acceleration.
From 1 to 3 seconds, velocity decreases indicating negative acceleration.
Between 1 and 2 seconds, velocity decreases from 20 m/s to 10 m/s; the slope is negative.
The slope of the graph between 1 and 2 seconds is negative, indicating negative acceleration.
To determine gradual decrease in acceleration, check if the slope is changing; the graph shows a curve indicating changing slope.
The slope is becoming less steep, meaning the magnitude of acceleration is decreasing.
The particle undergoes linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds because the slope is becoming less negative.
